messages: 2d19c57fdd4fdc270c971f69ee8d5169 (21:21): since when google.com uses <!doctype html> ?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:40): 2d19c57fdd4fdc270c971f69ee8d5169: Since several months ago, at least
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:41): 2d19c57fdd4fdc270c971f69ee8d5169: (though only on a few of their pages)

d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:04): Afternoon.  I'm trying to make some sense of the new HTML5 tags, and I want to be sure I understand their semantics.  <nav> vs. <menu>: it seems that both are to be used for navigation links...and yet only <menu> directly accepts <li>.  What is the proper way of using those tags?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:18): d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3: You probably want <nav>
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:19): <menu> is designed for building application menus but it isn't really supported yet
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:19): goes to check he isn't talking rubbish
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:20): nav is for primary navigation, menu is for something that I've never needed and thus can't remember what it is for

d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:20): The next question then: <article> vs <section>.  It seems that there are many sections per article, btu there can be many articles per page.  Is an article supposed to represent an entire page, or just the content usually between <header> and <footer>?  (I can rephrase if needed)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:22): d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3: You can have multiple <article>s per page
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:23): e.g. <article><h1>My first news item</h1></article> <article><h1>My second news item</h1></article>
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:23): ...and what if the items are not really...well, news/blog related?

d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:24): My original understanding: using a two column layout, <header> at top, <article> for main column, <nav>/<menu> for navigation on secondary column, <footer> on bottom.  Is this still valid thinking?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:24): That seems reasonable
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:25): ...long as I'm not required to have <header> and <footer> in <article>/<section>, I may be able to make something work.
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:25): I'm currently redesigning one of my websites, and I've been convinced to at least look into HTML5.  It seems to reduce my need for IDs at least.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:29): http://google.com/support/webmasters/bin/answer.py?answer=146898 - someone should tell them about <hX> elements instead of <strong>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:30): Aren't their CURIEs resulting in URIs like "http://rdf.data-vocabulary.orgreview"?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:32): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I suggest ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:33): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Huh?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:33): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: To tell them about hX
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:33): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: If only there were a google employee around who could file a bug
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:33): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: They don't seem to provide any way to provide feedback
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:33): so complaining on IRC is the most effective thing to do
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:45): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I guess a polarizing filter darkens the sky because the light in unpolarized and hence polarizing it makes it less intense?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:49): One example says xmlns:v="http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org/"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:49): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Well that is true
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:49): All the others say xmlns:v="http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:50): But it's not really the relevant fact

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:51): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: The point is that the light from the sky is partially polarised (because it is scattered light from the atmosphere and scattering polarises light in a way that depends on the angle of scattering)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:51): <spanspan property="v:locality">Springfield</span>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:51): I think they need to do a bit of QA on these help pages
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:52): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: And as a consequence, with the polarizer set to the right angle you can eliminate almost all of the scattering from the sky
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:52): s/scattering/light/
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:52): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: ah
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:52): (or t least from those regions of the sky that are heavilly polarised)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:53): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Is this a physics question or a photography question?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:53): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: a physics of photography question :)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:53): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: But evryone knows that http://example.com/ === http://example.com
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:53): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: (It's random curiosity, really, but from a physics POV)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:54): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Oh that's OK. If it's curiosity I don't need to worry to much about being right
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:54): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I do hope Google's implementation doesn't just look for the prefix "v:"
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:54): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Apart from generic URI parsers that don't know about what RFC2616 defines on-top about scheme specific normalization
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:55): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: "parsers" fail to meet the definition of "everybody" since "body" here specifically means "human body"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:55): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Didn't 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e say that the Google implementation of some microdata stuff just used regexps
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:56): ...if only the Tidy HTML Validator extension I had recognized HTML5, it would make things easier...
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:56): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yes
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:56): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: the page I'm working on is not live yet
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:57): http://html5.validator.nu/ is better actually
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:57): d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3: Either change the "Address" dropdown to "textarea"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:57): or go through some pain to get a local install
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (22:57): ...gotta love javascript powered fields

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:58): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: "Google's handling of RDF blocks for license declarations is all done with regular expressions instead of actually parsing the namespaces"
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (23:01): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: That sounds quite close if you s/microdata/license declarations/
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:04): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: For some reason I thought you said "RDFa" in your statement
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:04): but the evidence indicates that you didn't

d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (23:10): ...and with the help of the new HTML5 tags (and some abuse of child selectors), I've trimmed out the <divs> and id=s from my main page.  The other pages...will take some time.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:11): d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3: Has everything broken awfully in IE? :-)
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (23:11): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: javascript workaround. :P
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (23:12): honestly, I don't really care about IE

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:14): (Looking at http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org/rdf.xml, I guess xmlns:v="http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org" and xmlns:v="http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org/" are *both* wrong, and it ought to be xmlns:v="http://rdf.data-vocabulary.org/#")
d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (23:15): ...right, form elements should keep their IDs.  That's fine.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:15): (but presumably Google can add some hacks in their parser to make it all work)

d8441a460e8ac10414418e8e2c673ec3 (23:21): I'd like confirmation via this picture.  http://img509.imageshack.us/my.php?image=picture1kpe.png  Left sidebar uses <nav> & <ul> for its links.  Center, horizontal links use <ul> by itself, no <nav>.  Am I using the tags properly?
